metadata.title: 50-State Revenge Porn / Non-Consensual Intimate Image (NCII) Laws
metadata.notes: As of May 2025, all 50 states have enacted criminal revenge porn laws. South Carolina was the last state, enacting H. 3058 on May 12, 2025.
metadata.disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. Laws change frequently. Consult an attorney licensed in your state for legal guidance.

federalLaw.name: TAKE IT DOWN Act
federalLaw.summary: Criminalizes publication of non-consensual intimate images including AI-generated deepfakes. Requires social media platforms to remove NCII within 48 hours of victim notification. Creates federal criminal penalties.

additionalFederalRemedies.name: Violence Against Women Act Reauthorization Act of 2022
additionalFederalRemedies.summary: Provides federal civil remedy for victims of NCII, allowing lawsuits in federal court.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 10 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass, threaten, coerce, or intimidate

victimRemedies.notes: Criminal penalties only; civil remedies available under common law torts

states.summary: Alabama criminalizes distributing intimate images without consent with intent to harass. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Enhanced penalties for distribution for financial gain
states.summary: Alaska prohibits distributing intimate images of a person without consent when the images were obtained in a confidential relationship. Distribution for profit elevates to felony.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2.5 years (Class 5); up to 3.75 years (Class 4)

keyProvisions: Includes images depicting specific sexual activities

victimRemedies.notes: Civil cause of action under A.R.S. 12-761

states.summary: Arizona makes non-consensual distribution of intimate images a felony. Victims can pursue both criminal charges and civil lawsuits for damages and injunctive relief.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 6 years

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass, threaten, or coerce
states.summary: Arkansas classifies non-consensual disclosure of intimate images as a Class D felony when done to harass, threaten, or coerce the victim.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 6 months (first offense); up to 1 year (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to cause serious emotional distress
Victim must actually suffer emotional distress
Separate civil statute Cal. Civil Code 1708.85

victimRemedies.notes: Civil Code 1708.85 allows damages up to $150,000 per violation plus attorney fees

states.summary: California was an early adopter, criminalizing revenge porn as a misdemeanor. Victims can also sue for substantial civil damages under a separate statute.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 18 months (misdemeanor); up to 18 months (felony)

victimRemedies.notes: Civil cause of action under C.R.S. 13-21-1401

states.summary: Colorado criminalizes posting intimate images without consent. Repeat offenses become felonies. Victims have explicit civil remedies including injunctions and damages.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass, annoy, or alarm

victimRemedies.notes: Civil action available under Conn. Gen. Stat. 52-571j

states.summary: Connecticut criminalizes unlawful dissemination of intimate images with intent to harass. Repeat offenses are felonies. Civil remedies are also available.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 6 months

keyProvisions: Violation of privacy - distribution of intimate images

victimRemedies.notes: Criminal penalties only; civil remedies under common law

states.summary: Delaware makes distributing intimate images without consent a misdemeanor. Penalties are relatively modest compared to many states.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to cause substantial emotional distress

victimRemedies.notes: Explicit civil cause of action in statute

states.summary: Florida's sexual cyberharassment law criminalizes posting intimate images without consent. Repeat offenses are felonies. Victims can sue for damages and injunctions.

offenseLevel.first: Misdemeanor of high and aggravated nature

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); 1-5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Transmission of photography depicting nudity or sexually explicit conduct
states.summary: Georgia criminalizes transmitting intimate images without consent. First offense is a high misdemeanor; repeat offenses are felonies with significant penalties.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 5 years

keyProvisions: Violation of privacy in the second degree
states.summary: Hawaii makes non-consensual distribution of intimate images a Class C felony with up to 5 years imprisonment. It was one of the earliest states with a felony penalty.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 5 years

keyProvisions: Covers images taken with consent but distributed without
states.summary: Idaho classifies non-consensual distribution of intimate images as a felony with up to 5 years in prison. This applies even if the images were originally taken consensually.

maxPenalties.jail: 1-3 years (Class 4); 2-5 years (Class 3)

keyProvisions: Non-consensual dissemination of private sexual images
Threat to distribute is also criminal
states.summary: Illinois treats revenge porn as a felony even for first offenses. The law explicitly covers deepfakes and threats to distribute. Comprehensive civil remedies are available.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); 6 months-2.5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Enhanced penalties for distribution with intent to profit
states.summary: Indiana criminalizes distribution of intimate images without consent. Aggravated violations, such as distribution for profit, are felonies. Civil remedies include damages and injunctions.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2 years (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass or intimidate
states.summary: Iowa makes non-consensual distribution of intimate images an aggravated misdemeanor. Repeat offenses are Class D felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 11 months (felony w/guidelines)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass, threaten, or intimidate
states.summary: Kansas criminalizes non-consensual distribution of intimate images as a person offense. First violation is a misdemeanor; subsequent violations are felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); 1-5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Distribution of sexually explicit images without consent
Enhanced penalties for distribution involving minors
states.summary: Kentucky makes non-consensual distribution of intimate images a misdemeanor for first offenses and a felony for repeat offenses. Threats to distribute are also covered.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 6 months (first); up to 2 years (second); up to 5 years (third+)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $1,000 (first); up to $2,000 (second); up to $5,000 (third+)

keyProvisions: With intent to harass or cause emotional distress
states.summary: Louisiana criminalizes non-consensual disclosure of intimate images with progressive penalties. Third and subsequent offenses are felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (Class D); up to 5 years (Class C)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $2,000 (Class D); up to $5,000 (Class C)

keyProvisions: Violation of privacy through dissemination of intimate image
states.summary: Maine criminalizes non-consensual dissemination of intimate images. Repeat offenses carry heavier penalties. Victims can pursue civil remedies including damages and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2 years

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harm, harass, or intimidate

victimRemedies.notes: Civil action under Md. Courts & Judicial Proceedings 3-2001

states.summary: Maryland makes revenge porn a misdemeanor with up to 2 years imprisonment. Victims have civil remedies including damages, injunctions, and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2.5 years (first); up to 5 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Includes deepfakes and digitally altered images
states.summary: Massachusetts criminalizes revenge porn including deepfakes. First offense is a misdemeanor; subsequent offenses are felonies. Civil remedies are comprehensive.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 93 days (first); up to 1 year (second); up to 2 years (third+)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $500 (first); up to $1,000 (second); up to $5,000 (third+)

keyProvisions: Posting sexually explicit image without consent

victimRemedies.notes: Criminal penalties only; civil remedies under common law

states.summary: Michigan uses a progressive penalty structure for revenge porn. Third and subsequent offenses are felonies. The law requires the victim to be identifiable in the image.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (gross misdemeanor); up to 3 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Non-consensual dissemination of private sexual images
Enhanced penalties for profit motive or repeat offenses
states.summary: Minnesota criminalizes non-consensual dissemination of intimate images. Aggravated cases involving profit or repeat offenses are felonies. Civil remedies are available.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (first); up to 5 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Distribution of intimate images without consent
states.summary: Mississippi enacted its revenge porn law in 2021. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 4 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Non-consensual dissemination of private sexual images
Requires intent to harass, threaten, or coerce
states.summary: Missouri criminalizes non-consensual dissemination of intimate images with intent to harass. Repeat offenses are Class E felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 6 months

keyProvisions: Requires intent to cause emotional distress

victimRemedies.notes: Criminal penalties only; relatively light penalties

states.summary: Montana makes non-consensual distribution of intimate images a misdemeanor with relatively light penalties compared to many states.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 2 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Distribution of intimate images without consent
Requires intent to harass, threaten, or intimidate
states.summary: Nebraska criminalizes distribution of intimate images without consent. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are Class IV felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: 1-4 years

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to harass
states.summary: Nevada treats all revenge porn offenses as Category D felonies with 1-4 years imprisonment. This is one of the stricter state laws. Civil remedies are also available.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 7 years (felony)

states.summary: New Hampshire criminalizes non-consensual dissemination of intimate images. Repeat offenses are Class B felonies with up to 7 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: 3-5 years

keyProvisions: One of the earliest and strongest state laws
states.summary: New Jersey was the first state with a revenge porn law (2004). It remains one of the strictest, treating all offenses as third-degree crimes with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 18 months (felony)

victimRemedies.notes: Civil action available under separate statute

states.summary: New Mexico criminalizes unlawful distribution of intimate images. First offense is a misdemeanor; subsequent offenses are fourth-degree felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 4 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to cause harm

victimRemedies.notes: Civil action under N.Y. Civ. Rights Law 52-b

states.summary: New York criminalizes unlawful dissemination of intimate images. The state later added separate protections against deepfakes. Civil remedies are comprehensive.

maxPenalties.jail: 4-25 months (Class H); 15-63 months (Class E)

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to coerce, harass, or intimidate
states.summary: North Carolina treats all revenge porn offenses as felonies. First offenses are Class H felonies; repeat offenses are Class E felonies with significant prison terms.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 360 days (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

states.summary: North Dakota criminalizes unlawful distribution of intimate images. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are Class C felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 60 days (3rd degree); up to 180 days (1st degree)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $500 (3rd degree); up to $1,000 (1st degree)

keyProvisions: Non-consensual dissemination of private sexual images
With intent to harass, intimidate, or cause harm
states.summary: Ohio criminalizes revenge porn as a misdemeanor with relatively light criminal penalties but provides robust civil remedies including damages and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (first); up to 2 years (second); up to 5 years (third+)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $1,000 (first); up to $5,000 (second); up to $10,000 (third+)

keyProvisions: Requires intent to harass or cause harm
states.summary: Oklahoma uses a progressive penalty structure for revenge porn. Third and subsequent offenses are felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

states.summary: Oregon criminalizes unlawful dissemination of intimate images. Repeat offenses are felonies. Civil remedies include injunctions, compensatory damages, and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2 years (1st degree); up to 2 years (2nd degree)
maxPenalties.fines: Up to $5,000 (1st degree); up to $5,000 (2nd degree)

keyProvisions: Intent to harass, annoy, or alarm
states.summary: Pennsylvania criminalizes revenge porn as a misdemeanor. Civil remedies are available including damages, injunctions, and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (first); up to 3 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to harass
states.summary: Rhode Island criminalizes revenge porn. Repeat offenses are felonies. Victims can pursue civil remedies including damages and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 3 years (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

victimRemedies.notes: Criminal penalties only in initial law

states.summary: South Carolina was the last state to enact a revenge porn law, signed on May 12, 2025. The law covers deepfakes and provides criminal penalties for distribution without consent.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 2 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Distribution of intimate image without consent
With intent to threaten, harass, or intimidate
states.summary: South Dakota criminalizes distribution of intimate images without consent. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are Class 6 felonies.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 11 months 29 days (misdemeanor); 1-6 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to harm
states.summary: Tennessee criminalizes unlawful exposure of intimate images. Repeat offenses are Class E felonies. Civil remedies include damages and injunctive relief.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); 180 days-2 years (state jail felony)

keyProvisions: Unlawful disclosure of intimate visual material
Without consent and with intent to harm

victimRemedies.notes: Civil action under Tex. Civ. Prac. & Rem. Code 98B

states.summary: Texas criminalizes unlawful disclosure of intimate visual material. Repeat offenses are state jail felonies. Civil remedies include statutory damages up to $10,000 per violation.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (misdemeanor); up to 5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: Distribution of intimate image without consent
Requires intent to cause harm or distress
states.summary: Utah criminalizes distribution of intimate images without consent. Repeat offenses are third-degree felonies. Civil remedies include injunctions and damages.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 2 years (first); up to 5 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Disclosure of sexually explicit images without consent
With intent to harm, harass, or threaten
states.summary: Vermont criminalizes disclosure of intimate images without consent. Repeat offenses are felonies. Civil remedies are built into the criminal statute.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 12 months (misdemeanor); 1-5 years (felony)

keyProvisions: With intent to coerce, harass, or intimidate
states.summary: Virginia criminalizes unlawful dissemination of intimate images. Repeat offenses are Class 6 felonies. Civil remedies include compensatory damages and attorney fees.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 364 days

keyProvisions: Without consent and with intent to harm
states.summary: Washington criminalizes disclosure of intimate images as a gross misdemeanor. The law was updated in 2024 to explicitly cover AI-generated deepfakes.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (first); 1-5 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: Non-consensual disclosure of private intimate images
With intent to harass, intimidate, or coerce
states.summary: West Virginia criminalizes non-consensual disclosure of intimate images. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 9 months (misdemeanor); up to 3.5 years (felony)

states.summary: Wisconsin criminalizes non-consensual distribution of intimate images. Repeat offenses are Class I felonies. Civil remedies include damages.

maxPenalties.jail: Up to 1 year (first); up to 5 years (subsequent)

keyProvisions: With intent to harass, annoy, or alarm
states.summary: Wyoming criminalizes non-consensual dissemination of intimate images. First offense is a misdemeanor; repeat offenses are felonies with up to 5 years imprisonment.
